conclusion: Apply Snell's Law to relate angles of incidence and refraction to find the refractive index of the liquid.
Light travels in a straight line and hits point a on the left wall when the tank is empty.
Light refracts at the surface of the liquid when the tank is filled.
Use Snell's Law: n1 sin(i) = n2 sin(r), where n1 is the refractive index of air and n2 is the refractive index of the liquid.
Height h and horizontal distance L form a right triangle with the path of the light when the tank is empty.
Angle of incidence i can be found using the tangent function: tan(i) = (H - h) / L, therefore i = tan^(-1)((H - h) / L).
Horizontal distance from the point of incidence on the liquid surface to the wall is L when the tank is filled.
Angle of refraction r can be found using the tangent function: tan(r) = H / L, therefore r = tan^(-1)(H / L).
Substitute angles into Snell's Law: sin(i) = sin(tan^(-1)((H - h) / L)), sin(r) = sin(tan^(-1)(H / L)).
Snell's Law becomes: sin(tan^(-1)((H - h) / L)) = n2 sin(tan^(-1)(H / L)).
Calculate sines using identity: sin(tan^(-1)(x)) = x / sqrt(1 + x^2).
sin(i) = (H - h) / sqrt(L^2 + (H - h)^2), sin(r) = H / sqrt(L^2 + H^2).
Solve for refractive index n2: (H - h) / sqrt(L^2 + (H - h)^2) = n2 H / sqrt(L^2 + H^2).
The refractive index of the liquid is n2 = ((H - h) sqrt(L^2 + H^2)) / (H sqrt(L^2 + (H - h)^2)).
